awd_titl_txt: A Framework of Algorithms & Simulator for Quantum Mechanical Modeling of Nanodevices
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: The proposed research seeks to develop novel algorithms and a simulator to quantum
mechanically model nanoscale devices in both two and three-dimensions. Algorithms will be developed to model both the dc and ac current response. The focus of the proposed work is on a broad range of nanodevice structures within the effective mass and tight binding approaches. Examples of these structures include devices based on carbon nanotubes, graphene, silicon nanowires and quantum well superlattices.

Intellectual merit: The proposed work combines the expertise of co-PIs from electrical engineering and applied mathematics departments to probe the physics of nanodevices accurately and efficiently using the Green?s function approach. The developed algorithms will be applicable to devices in the areas of low power / voltage and energy applications. Further, the approach has the potential for a significant improvement in the simulation speed over current widely used approaches for steady state simulations with decoherence.

Broader impacts: The proposed research will involve training of both graduate and undergraduate students in methods to model nanodevices and the study of their underlying device physics. We will make an effort to involve female students and students from underrepresented groups.  Both electrical engineering courses on devices and an applied mathematics course on high performance computing will leverage this research to explore nanodevices and algorithms respectively. Outreach to high school students will occur by interactions to illustrate the role of modeling and simulation in discovery and technology development.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Computational methods to model nanoscale devices and materials hold great promise for exploration of new ideas. In addition, computational studies help by decreasing expenditure before moving to the important but expensive experimental steps of fabrication, characterization and testing of devices. The most challenging area in developing computational device modeling methods is to find algorithms to efficiently solve equations. This area is challenging because it requires collaboration between experts in devices, physics, applied mathematics and computer science. In this ECCS Division supported project, electrical engineering and applied mathematics co-PIs collaborated in designing a new algorithm to model the current flow in nanodevices using quantum mechanical methods. The developed algorithm is up to 250 times faster than the current fastest algorithm. The algorithm and accompanying code has been publicly released. In addition, a number of journal articles have been published.

The computational method developed was applied to study the device physics of two-dimensional heterostructure devices made up of graphene and Boron Nitride. Using our algorithm and code, we were able to determine the importance of scattering on the performance of a device exhibiting Negative Differential Resistance (devices exhibiting this property can be used to build new kinds of logic gates and high-speed oscillators). We were also able to determine that these devices can potentially operate at room temperature, which is important for applications.

We conducted a serious study of the performance of our algorithms for two and three dimensional device Hamiltonians that exhibit a dense matrix structure, and time dependent studies. We found that while the technique that we have developed provides a significantly faster method to calculate the current versus voltage characteristics of  technologically promising two and quasi-two dimensional devices, there is a dire need for the development of radically new algorithms for three-dimensional devices and for time-dependent device modeling studies.

This project provided a platform for the development of highly qualified personnel in areas of electrical engineering and allied algorithm development. The proposal supported one graduate student’s doctoral thesis and provided a platform for faculty members in electrical engineering and applied mathematics to co-supervise this graduate student. The technical aspects of the proposal also provided training for three Seattle-area high school students, two undergraduate students, and one visiting postdoctoral fellow, in the field of nanodevices. The high school students have gone on to pursue careers in engineering and science.  

The following publications were supported by this work:

  1. Gunn Effect in Silicon Nanowires: Charge Transport under High Electric Field, Daryoush Shiri, Amit Verma, Reza Nekovei, Andreas Isacsson, C. R. Selvakumar, M. P. Anantram, arXiv:1709.01862 ; https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.01862
  2. Extenuated interlayer scattering in double-layered graphene/hexagonal boron nitride heterostructure, Nikhil Jain, Fan Yang, Robin B. Jacobs-Gedrim, Xu Xu, M. P. Anantram, Bin Yu, Carbon, Volume 126, Pages 17-22, (2018);  https://doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2017.09.074
  3. Photo absorption enhancement in strained silicon nanowires: An atomistic study,   Daryoush Shiri, M. Golam Rabbani, Jianqing Qi, Andrei K. Buin, and M. P. Anantram, Journal of Applied Physics, volume 122, pages 034302 (2017); doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4993587 
  4. Negative Differential Resistance in Graphene Boron Nitride Heterostructure Controlled by Twist and Phonon-Scattering, Y. Zhao, Z. Wan, U. Hetmanuik, M. P. Anantram, IEEE Electron Device Letters, vol. 37 (9), pages 1242-1245 (2016); DOI: 10.1109/LED.2016.2595522
  5. Nested dissection solver for transport in 3D nano-electronic devices, Y Zhao, U Hetmaniuk, SR Patil, J Qi, MP Anantram, Journal of Computational Electronics 15 (2), 708-720 (2016); DOI: 10.1007/s10825-015-0778-x
  6. Negative Differential Resistance in Boron Nitride Graphene Heterostructures: Physical Mechanisms and Size Scaling Analysis, Y. Zhao, Z. Wan, X. Xu, S. R. Patil, U. Hetmaniuk, M. P. Anantram Scientific reports, volume 5, pages 1-10 (2015) doi:10.1038/srep10712
  7. A Reduced-Order Method for Coherent Transport Using Green's Functions, U. Hetmaniuk, D. Ji, Y. Zhao, M. P. Anantram IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices, volume 62, pages 736-742 (2015) DOI: 10.1109/TED.2015.2395420
  8. A nested dissection approach to modeling transport in nanodevices: Algorithms and applications, Ulrich Hetmaniuk, Yunqi Zhao, M. P. Anantram, International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering, DOI: 10.1002/nme.4518 (2013)
  9. Ab-initio analysis of melting point and optical properties in doped phase change memory materials, Evan Wang , Yunqi Zhao, Xu Xu, Jeong-Sun Moon, and M. P. Anantram, To be submitted
